editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: ΣΥΝ Θ ΕΩ

Conſilium Hygiaſticum, Pro Illuſtriſſ. Excellentiſſ
que Heroë, Dno. JOHANNE LUCA, Marchione DURAZZO, Extraordinario Sereniſsimae Reip. GENUENSIS Oratore, ad Auguſtiſsimum CAROLUM II. Magnae Britanniae Regem, honorificentiſsimè miſſo, & ab eodem paritèr excepto, Anno hoc, Aerae Christi nati, MDCLXI.
div.p:
QUUM ex rationali, & ad ſanctiores Artis Apollineae leges accuratiſsimè inſtituto Stochaſmo, nobis planè plenèque compertum ſit, Nobiliſsimum Virum contumacioribus viſcerum
Nutricatui officialium, maximè verò Meſenterii ac Lienis obſtructionibus impenſe obnoxium eſſe; eòque forſan nomine, Affectione Hypochondriaca ſubinde moleſtatum fuiſſe, annis aliquot retrò abhinc elapſis, & non ita pridem graviori etiam Febre Tertiana; quumque omnimoda affectum horum eradicatio potiſsimùm ſperari debeat ab uſu eorum remediorum, quae obſtructis ac Hypochondriacis certiſſimam ſpondent medelam: Eapropter, Eum humillimè duximus monendum, adhortandumque, ut, quamprimùm Patriae felicitèr redditus fuerit, inſequentia Medicamenta, tempore, modo, ac ordine praeſcriptis, alacritèr uſurpando, ſaluti ſuae proſpiciat; impraeſentiarum quidem (quod lugendum) vix ſatis conſtanti, aſt omnibus melioris Genii hominibus haud immeritò chariſsimae.

Exordium, igitur, commodiſsimè ſumatur â benigniori primarum viarum
ablutione: cui ſcopo adprimè ſatiſfaciet hujuſmodi Apozema ſolutivum.

℞
Decoct. Sennae & Tamarindorum, in aqua Hordeacea facti, ℥ iij. ſs.
Aceti Sambucini recentioris, ʒ vj.
Rhabarbari optimi, minutìm inciſi, ʒ j. ſs.
Agarici albiſsimi, pariter in fruſtula ſecti, ʒ j.
Seminum Foeniculi dulcis, & Carui contuſorum, ana ℈ ſs.
Florum Macis amplior. Gr. vj.

Maceratione per 3. horulas, ad lentiorem cinerum calorem, factâ, tranſcolatòque liquore, denuò admiſceantur.
Syruporum Cichorei cum Rheo, & Roſarum ſolutivi, ana ʒ vj.
Tartari Vitriolati, Gr. vij.
Ut fiat Potio, mane mox poſt ſolis exortum ſumenda, cum regimine purgativo.

Impuritatibus è prima corporis regione,
viſcerumque confiniis, hoc pacto, cum Euphoria, exterminatis; poſtera luce celebranda veniet Phlebotomia: quae dextrè adminiſtrari poſsit in magis conſpicua vena cubiti dextri; unde effluere permittantur ſanguinis ℥ vij, aut circiter. Hoc autem Illuſtriſſ. Marchioni ſeriò perſuadere nobis viſum eſt, duplicem quidem ob conſiderationem: nimirum, ut per detractionem iſtam moderatam aliquantulùm imminuto ſanguinis pleonaſmo, quicquid in vaſis ſupereſt, liberiùs expeditiúſque per univerſum corpus ſuos peragat circuitus; utque tempeſtivè exonerentur viſcerum penetralia, plenioribus ejuſdem Laticis purpurei rivulis infarcta, & aliquatenus diſtenta. Experientia quippe multiplici ſumus edocti, prudentèr inſtitutam venae ſectionem, quicquid in Arterioſo venosòque genere redundat, deplere; diſtentum relaxare; inflammationi pronum contemperare; denique tum carnes, tum vaſula 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 reddere.

Proximum locum ſibi ex ordine vendicant Deobſtruentia mitiora; talia tamen, quae craſſos, viſcidos, ſalinos, faecumque vini aemulos ſuccos, in anguſtioribus Meſenterii meandris coacervatos, attenuando, incidendo, exagitando, ſensìm ſubmoveant, praeparentque ad commodiorem ſuo tempore deturbationem. Quocirca, ſanguinis miſsionem citò excipiat uſus Apozematis hujus deoppilativi.

℞
Radicum quinque Aperitivarum, ana ℥ ij.
Oſmundi regalis ſiccat. ℥ j. ſs.
Aſari ℥ ſs.
Corticum radicum Capparum, & Tamariſci, ana ʒ vj.
Folior. Agrimoniae, Ceterach, ITEMinguae Cervinae, ana, M. j.
Flor. Sambuci, Cichorei, Geniſtae, ana M. ſs.
Uvarum Corinthiacarum, à ſordibus repurgatarum, ℥ ij.
Seminum Endiviae, & Aquilegiae, ana ʒ ij.
Tartari ad Albedinem niveam loti, ℥ j.

Inciſa & contuſa leniter coquantur, ad B. M. calorem, per horam unam & alteram, in partibus aequalibus vini albi Oligophori, & Aquae Fluvialis, ut poſt decoctionem ſaturatam remaneant Liquoris Librae tres. Quibus exquiſitè colatis, & clarificatis tandem affundantur
Syrupi è ſucco Fumariae, ℥ vj.
Spirit. Vitrioli, ſaepiùs rectificat, ℈ ij.
Ut conficiatur Apozema, de quo, mane, & appetente jam veſperâ, exhibeantur ℥ v. continuò per triduum; abſtinendo interim ab Epulis veſpertinis.
Huic autem proximè ſuccedat levior Catharſis, ex hujuſmodi Catapotiis.

℞
Pilular. Hierae cum Agarico, ℈j. ſs.
Reſinae Zalapii, Gr. viij.
Elixir. proprietatis Paracelſi Guttulas quot ſufficiant.

E commixtis formentur Pilulae quinque, auro obryzo foliato honeſtandae, primàque luce, in pulpa pomi Buxtorfiani aſſari, deglutiendae: ſuperhauriendo ſerum lactis vaccini, ſucco Aurantii acidioris ſequeſtratum, atque ad jucunditatem ſaporis ſaccharatum; idque toties quoties ventrem laxaverint.

Poſtridie hujus purgationis ſecundae, peropportunum erit ad Ecphractica generoſiora progredi. Quorum è cenſu, caeteris omnibus palmam dudum jam praeripuiſſe perhibentur è Chalybe compoſita: non, mehercule, (ut rem, quam 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , multi mirantur, pauci verò intelligunt, obiter heic ſubinnuere liceat) reſpectu Sulphuris illius, quod Chalybi inſitum, virtute quadam pollere creditur inſignitèr
inciſoria, quemadmodum precariò ſtatuunt plerique è Practicis; ſed multo veriſimiliùs quòd mala Hypochondriaca ferè omnia à Fermentationis vi proficiſci videantur; eidemque compeſcendae Chalybs ſummoperè conducat. Quippe ſi Aceto etiam acerrimo (cui ſeroſa Melancholicorum colluvies certè haud multum abſimilis exiſtit) limaturam ejus, per noctis ſpatium, indiderit quis; poſtridie pro aceto aquam inveniet, omni acore ſpoliatam. Caeterum, utcunque ſe habeat haec res, praelonga, nec improſpera ſanè Experientia ſancitum fatemur, Chalybeata reſerandis viſcerum obſtructionibus convenire eximiè: proindeque Nos viro Ampliſsimo authores eſſe nulli dubitamus, eorum uſum in ſe admittere nec recuſet, nec ultrà hic definitam 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 differat; eâ tamen lege, ut vitentur ea, quae ſupra modum aut calefacere poſsint, aut exſiccare; & ut talibus conſociantur, quae
alvum quotidiè muneris ſui commonefaciant. Laudamus itaque Pilulas Martis, hujuſmodi artificio confectas.

℞
Maſſae Pilular. Hierae cum Agarico, ʒ j.
Rhabarbari optimi pulverat, ℈ ij.
ITEMimaturae Chalybis puriſsimae, in pollinem ſubtiliſsimum redactae, ℈ j. ſs.
Extracti Centaurei minoris, ʒ j.
Salis Abſinthii, ℈ ſs.
Terebinthinae Cypriae, quantum ſatis ſit, ut lentore ejus conſiſtentiam induant pilularem caetera commiſta.

E maſſula hac formentur Pilulae mediocres, auro decorandae, & pondere ℈ ij. ſumendae, ſingulis auroris, per dies viginti. Obſervandum autem praeterea, ut poſt unamquamque doſin & ſuperbibatur ſerum lactis vaccini, in quo Flores Cichorei & Borraginis
incocti fuerint; & ut moderatè exerceatur corpus, per horulam unam & alteram, vel (ſi ferant vires) ampliùs: ex utròque enim facultates Ecphracticῶn haud parùm promovebuntur.

Porro dum haec peraguntur, ſummè proficuum fore arbitramur, ſi Illuſtriſſ. Marchio ſe in Balneum Aquae dulcis, bis tervè in ſeptimana, ad humeros uſque (ſi modo id ferre valeat, ſin minùs ſemicupium ſubrogari poterit) immergeret. Quandoquidem Galenus (8. de loc. affect. cap. 6.) refert, ſolis Balneis aquarum dulcium ſe multos Melancholicos curaſſe, abſque ullo alio medicamento. Nec ſine ſontica cauſa profectò. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 quippe, ſive redundantia Seri in Lienoſis, quae proculdubio eſt 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , fons eorum, quae ſunt in corpore, malorum, ut loquitur divinus
Senex (lib. de Flatibus 2. text. 19.) tam per inconſpicua cutis ſpiracula, quàm per Urinas evacuari expoſcit.

Abſoluto tandem, quicquid ad expediendos viſcerum infarctus, humoreſque vitioſos, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , per loca lege Naturae commodiora, pedetentim educendos, videretur requiſitum; nil aliud agendum reſtabit, ſperamus, quàm ut partium malè affectarum intemperies, & 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ſucceſsivè corrigantur: id quod haud difficulter praeſtabunt Corroborantia. Quorum è ſylva ſequens ſeligeremus Electuarium, menſe integro dietìm uſurpandum.

℞
Pulpae Paſſularum Corinthiacarum, vino Hiſpanico polygophoro decentèr extractae, & per ſetaceum trajectae, ℥ iiij.
Conſerv. Florum Borraginis & Bugloſſae, ana ℥ ij.
Confect. Alchermes, ℥ j.
Pulver. è chelis Cancror. marium ſimplicis, & Laetitiae Galeni, ana ʒ ij.
Raſurae Cornu Cervini, & Eboris pulverat, ana ʒ j. ſs.
Margaritarum praeparat. ʒ j.
Syrupor. è Corticibus Citriorum, & è Coralliis ſimplic. ana quantum ſufficiat.

Ut fiat Conditum; cujus, mane, & ſub veſperam, detur Duella: ſuperhauſto Cyatho duplici Vini Rhenani Bacharacenſis, floribus Cichorei, Borraginis & Bugloſſae impraegnati, nec non ſucci Aurantii pauxillo aculeati.

Diaetae regimen quod attinet, non eſt, profectò, cur ſuper eo admodum ſolliciti eſſemus, aut curioſi. Nam Magnificentiſſ. Heros tam ſtrictè ſobrius eſt, atque abſtemius; ut minimè metuendum, Ipſum gulae indulgendo valetudini
ſuae unquam incommodaturum: tam prudens, ut appetitui ſuo fraena injicere probè noverit; ab Hippocrate noſtro dudum edoctus, quòd 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , habet unaquaeque eſca, quo proſit, vel obſit.

Jam verò finem ſcriptiunculae huic impoſiturus, primùm me converto ad Te, Deus ter Opt. Max. animarum juxta ac corporum Archiater: divinam Miſericordiam Tuam ſupplex accedo, rogoque, ut auxiliis omnibus ac ſingulis à me heic praeſcriptis adeſſe velit, & benedictione ſingulari adſpirare, ne optato ſucceſſu fruſtrentur.

Deinde me converto ad TE, Marchionum Nobiliſsime, qui oraculum es inclytiſsimi Senatus veſtri, & totius Liguriae ſpes. TIBI ſummas ago gratias, quòd tenuitatem meam dignatus es in re maximi momenti, ſcilicet Sanitatis Tuae, conſulere: Teque ſubmiſſè rogo,
etiam digneris in hoc Conſilio, qualecunque ſit, agnoſcere voluntatem officioſam, promptam, ſinceram, quamque habere me decet ad omne omnino Excellentiae Tuae obſequium. Vale, Vir Excellentiſsime, & ad Neſtoreos uſque annos illibata ſanitate perfruere. Ita toto animo vovet

closer.signed: EXCELLENTIAE TUAE cultorum humillimus, Devotiſsimus, GUALTERUS CHARLETONUS, M.D. & Auguſtiſsimi CAROLI II. Magnae, Britanniae Regis Medicus Ordinarius.
